channel.title: Arch Linux
channel.description:
So I'm switching over to Arch. I've always run either *ubuntu, Mandriva, or Gentoo, so I'm wondering if it's very different from other flavors of Linux. I understand how it works, and that it's fully customizable, but once I get what I want installed, what makes it so much different from just using *Ubuntu and removing the packages I don't want and adding the ones I do. Because if it isn't that much different, I may not do it.
I'm sure part of using Arch Linux is having bragging rights... right?
EDIT: I decided to go ahead and make the leap. But I've hit a road block. I chose the core installation, and I am trying to get a GUI on Arch now, but I don't know how to go about getting one through Arch. I tried Pacman, but I get some error... Something about the "C locale" or something. Is there any other way? Possibly putting the xfce package on the root of the installation?

item.description:
@llib wrote:

I printed out the begginers guide (something close to 40ish pages o.O) although it was ok because I used the school’s printer

Anyway I followed that and didn’t have any issues with my install…although before I had Xorg and a GUI and everything I had to

dhcpcd eth0

To get the internet working on it before I could download anything. Then you have to download Xorg, video drivers, set up audio…you can’t just simply download xfce4. Just follow the begginers guide, helps a lot. I would recommend installing it again (with the guide step by step) because it sounds like you’ve already messed up somewhere.

item.title: Arch Linux
item.dc:creator: @Mopman Mopman
item.description:
@Mopman wrote:

The locale error can be safely ignored, it’s not going to be the cause of your problem (but you should fix it one day, see ArchWiki “Locale”)

If you have onboard Intel Wireless Lan, you have to enable the drivers manually, because of licensing issues. You will get the message whether you have Intel Wireless or not, so you only need to worry about this if you do.

Can you do “traceroute www.google.com” and “lspci” and stick them in a pastebin somewhere?
